title: 115_hr1653
content: The "Drinking Water Affordability Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes amendments to the Safe Drinking Water Act. The "Drinking Water Affordability Act" includes amendments to the Safe Drinking Water Act regarding national drinking water regulations, enforcement, and state revolving loan funds. Amendments include requirements for the promulgation of revisions to regulations and changes to assistance for disadvantaged communities. The Drinking Water Act is amended to include a provision for fully amortized loans within 30 years of project completion, with the option for disadvantaged communities to extend the term up to 40 years if it aligns with the project's design life. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to extend the term of fully amortized loans to 18 months after project completion for fiscal years 2018 through 2024. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to exempt certain program requirements approved under section 1453, excluding activities under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. SEC. 1459C provides an exemption from federal cross-cutting requirements. The Safe Drinking Water Act exempts public water systems receiving financial assistance from Federal cross-cutting requirements if the state has an equivalent or stricter requirement in place. A Federal cross-cutting requirement is defined as a condition for receiving financial assistance that overlaps with existing requirements. The Safe Drinking Water Act exempts public water systems from Federal cross-cutting requirements if the state has an equivalent or stricter requirement in place. SEC. 3. REPORTS. State Loan Fund Administration and Application Process: The EPA will review best practices for streamlining the application process for public water systems to receive loans from State drinking water treatment funds. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 18 months of this Act's enactment. The report will include a study on cost-effective ways to rehabilitate or replace drinking water infrastructure to meet Safe Drinking Water Act goals, as well as an assessment of barriers preventing communities from using studied materials and technologies.
